stream_context.summary: Kaze models and designs Course 11, “Oily Boily Bay,” adding wind-turbine and crane mechanics, placing red coins, and discussing camera tweaks, performance, and option philosophy.

development_findings.summary: The hack is at Course 11 of 15; ROM size is 42.8 MB, safely under the 64 MB N64 limit.
development_findings.quote: We’re in course 11 and we are 42.8 megabytes in size, so …

development_findings.summary: Course 11 is now mostly modeled; programming phase will begin after finishing the red-coin section.
New platform mechanic: vertical and horizontal wind turbines that blow Mario; timers control on/off states for timing challenges.
development_findings.quote: I definitely want one red coin you get by just jumping on a turbine and going up.

development_findings.summary: Cranes now support attachable hooks so Mario can grab moving platforms; implemented by spawning two actors that auto-attach.
development_findings.quote: We just put two actors next to each other and then one of the actor automatically just attaches to the other actor.

development_findings.summary: Camera was re-tuned after Lilaa’s feedback, showing willingness to iterate on UX.
development_findings.quote: Lilaa was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

development_findings.summary: Blue-coin switch needs a visual redesign; current placeholder judged ugly.
development_findings.quote: It’s about time we find something that works … otherwise we might just settle for an HD version of the original.

development_findings.summary: Solved severe gimbal-lock issue when rotating turbine models; final fix was rotating the mesh 90° in Blender and exporting as a separate model.
development_findings.quote: MFs will never believe you how hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

development_findings.summary: Engine rewrite plus cache-box optimization boosted real-N64 performance (e.g., Course 1 now ~40–50 FPS with infinite draw distance; Zoo went from 9 FPS to ~40).
development_findings.quote: I literally don’t even think it’s crazy to say anymore that this looks like a GameCube game.

development_findings.summary: 20 FPS interpolation bug causes visual flicker; flagged for future fix.
Current build is fast but unstable, occasionally crashing; stability work planned.
Considered “bubble” safety mechanic but rejected it for encouraging lame, grindy play; prefers designing difficulty properly.
development_findings.quote: It adds a lot of misery to the game and takes away the tension.

development_findings.summary: Contemplating whether final level should be extremely hard; may rely on optional post-game stars to buffer casual players.
development_findings.quote: I’m a little horrified … having a super hard final level is only really reasonable if there’s a lot of content casual players are not gonna touch.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s bike was stolen, putting him in a bad mood at stream start.
context_findings.quote: I’m in a bad mood because my bike was stolen.

context_findings.summary: He has tennis elbow; doctor suggested cortisol injections and painkillers, which he declined.
context_findings.quote: He diagnosed me with a tennis elbow … I said nah.

context_findings.summary: Prefers not to buy things; jokes he likes having money.
context_findings.quote: I never buy anything. I hate buying stuff. I like having money.

context_findings.summary: Believes YouTube’s meta favors long, background-noise videos; shapes his content strategy.
context_findings.quote: You’re not supposed to make engaging videos; you’re supposed to make videos that can be listened to in the background.

context_findings.summary: Transitioning streams from Twitch to YouTube; hit personal record of ~50 viewers.
context_findings.quote: Shout-outs to 50 viewers today, that is a new record for YouTube.

biobak.summary: Looking for lost turbine texture PSD; offers to recreate and later sends replacement assets.
biobak.quote: The only issue I have is trying to track the damn thing down … it might just be faster to recreate it.

biobak.summary: Provided new stream-banner artwork during the session.

key_stories.title: Wind Turbine Rotation Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Implementing turbines exposed a gimbal-lock issue where no combination of pitch, roll, or yaw produced correct rotation. After exhaustive debugging, Kaze rotated the mesh 90° in Blender and exported a new model, finally achieving proper spin.
key_stories.challenge: Euler-angle gimbal lock prevented desired rotation.
key_stories.process: Tried code-side axis tweaks, tested each, debug-printed values, then altered the source model.
key_stories.outcome: Both vertical and horizontal turbines now function, unlocking new platforming possibilities.
key_stories.key_quote: You will never believe how hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

key_stories.title: Course 1 Performance Showcase
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrated the optimized engine on real N64 hardware, showing Course 1 running at console-quality speeds with infinite draw distance.
key_stories.challenge: Original engine struggled at single-digit FPS on complex scenes.
key_stories.process: Implemented cache-box optimization and broader engine rewrite.
key_stories.outcome: Levels now hit ~40–50 FPS; visual fidelity likened to GameCube era.
key_stories.key_quote: This is an N64 game—how crazy is that?

key_stories.title: Option Anxiety
key_stories.summary: Chat requested numerous toggles (old fonts, health bars, etc.). Kaze debated the merit of endless options versus cohesive design.
key_stories.outcome: Decided to avoid trivial options and design around a single, clear vision.
key_stories.key_quote: At that point, just make your own game.

key_stories.title: The Great Texture Hunt
key_stories.summary: A missing PSD for turbine textures stalled progress. Biobak searched backups, then volunteered to remake the texture and sent assets to Kaze.
key_stories.process: Searched archives; concluded recreation was faster; delivered new files.
key_stories.outcome: Turbine received appropriate texture; modeling continued uninterrupted.
key_stories.key_quote: If I can’t find the file back, I can just remake it—it literally took 30 seconds to make.

open_questions.context: Current switch is considered ugly; Kaze and Lilaa want a new look but have no final concept.
questions: What visual language should the new blue-coin switch use?
How will it immediately communicate its function to players?
Who is leading the redesign and what is the timeline?

open_questions.context: Kaze is torn between a brutally hard finale and accessibility for casual players.
questions: How will you decide the final course’s difficulty ceiling?
Could optional post-game content satisfy hardcore players without blocking others?
What play-testing methods will inform this balance?

open_questions.context: Current build is fast but crashes; 20 FPS interpolation bug remains.
questions: What specific stability tasks remain before release?
How is real-hardware testing integrated into the pipeline?
Who on the team focuses on engine maintenance now?

open_questions.context: Idea of purchasable ‘bubbles’ for void protection was rejected for design reasons.
questions: How will difficulty spikes be smoothed without compromising challenge?
Would optional assist modes be considered post-launch?

open_questions.context: Biobak supplies textures; Lilaa gives design feedback; little mention of composer Badub or animator Zeina.
questions: How do core contributors coordinate tasks and version control?
What tools manage asset hand-offs and feedback loops?
How are schedules balanced, especially with Zeina’s animation work and Badub’s music pipeline?
